results.title: Shakespeare out loud: Cicely Berry workshop [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: Several prominent Australian actors take part in a workshop conducted by Cicely Berry OBE, Vocal Coach with the Royal Shakespeare Company for the past 30 years who has practiced her skills internationally with a diverse range of people. Attendees of the master class share what they’ve learnt from the experience and the effectiveness of working on the exercises in a group comprising of English and drama practitioners. Participants include: Barry Otto, Lucy Cornell, Olivia Pigeot, Belinda Bromilow, John Adam, Christopher Stollery, Peter Hambleton, Mary Docker, Peter Feeney.

results.title: Shakespeare is alive and well in the modern world
results.creator_credit: Barbara Winard and Centre for Humanities
results.brief_description: This interesting program is a very useful resource for students investigating the works of Shakespeare. It is structured in three parts and examines the treatment of alienation, love, revenge and humour in a discussion of “Romeo and Juliet” and “Hamlet”; ambition, violence and the nature of evil in “Macbeth” and rebellion and the power of words in “Julius Caesar”. By using footage from feature films, we see how the same themes have been treated in texts such as “Animal Farm”, “Mutiny on the Bounty” and “The Outsiders.”
results.title_for_label: Shakespeare is alive and well in the modern world

results.title: Shakespeare and Kronborg
results.brief_description: Kronborg Castle in Helsingor, the probable inspiration for Shakespeare’s “Hamlet”. Re-enacts a visit to the castle in 1600 by a group of English players, which Shakespeare may have accompanied, evokes the atmosphere of the castle and shows a Danish company in the annual summer performances of “Hamlet” in the castle courtyard. Script by Carl Theodor Dreyer.

results.title: Shakespeare's country
results.brief_description: The countryside, towns and villages around Stratford-upon-Avon and the Shakespearian associations of the district. Oxford, Stratford-upon-Avon, Warwick Castle, the Cotswolds. The old coaching inns and the Regency spas of Leamington and Cheltenham, villages and their gardens.

results.title: Shadows on the snow = Skuggor over snon
results.creator_credit: Arne Sucksdorff, Kort Film and Svensk Filmindustri
results.brief_description: In the winter forest, a bear frightens a small boy whose father then sets out with his dog to track the huge animal. The chase lasts into the darkness, where even this experienced hunter retreats in panic, for as Sucksdorff characteristically says he realises “that senses stronger than his are masters of the night”. Full of the beauty and the terror of the struggle to live, it also displays the distinctive Scandinavian approach to nature in which, “wood, wind and water are still alive”.

results.title: Shadow play
results.creator_credit: Arthur Cantrill, Corinne Cantrill and Children's Library and Craft Movement
results.brief_description: Children are given guidance in cutting-out and preparing figures for a shadow play. Children learn to make Japanese style flat paper puppets, after being shown a play at their Creative Leisure Centre in Brisbane. After deciding upon a story to illustrate, each child draws and cuts out outlines, gluing on lace, and paper doily frilly finishes and painting black for maximum effect. Finally scenery is fixed to the cloth screen, sound effects and puppets tried out and a bright light shone on the screen ready for the performance of St George and the Dragon, narrated by an instructor.

results.title: Shades of grey
results.brief_description: A fictional drama which portrays an American company investigating the incidence of sexual harassment within its own organisation. In doing so, it attempts to develop a wide-reaching concept, interpretation and definition of sexual harrassment.

results.title: Shades of difference
results.creator_credit: Frank Heimans and Cinetel Film Production Services
results.brief_description: Displays and discusses the work of two Australian painters, with their own explanations and responses to the comments of a random selection of people asked to view their works. Michael Dulics uses pictorial symbolism as a vehicle for social commentary. Col Jordan creates abstract optical effects.
